content.description: This route follows a pretty direct line in a large dihedral, and then over a roof. It's on the right half of the east face of The Sentinel.This is a great route, with the crux in the lower half of the dihedral, and an incredible no-hands "head rest" just below the roof.

Go up and right following happy jugs that lead to a steep left-facing juggy flake.  Good pumpy fun.  Once gaining a big ledge, continue up a flared grainy crack past a horizontal to connect to another flared grainy crack that tops out on the formation shoulder.  Could also do only the juggy flake and forgo the grainy cracks, to stop at the big ledge and scramble off to climber's left.  Quick fun that way when the popular routes are busy.
content.location: Located on the far right of the east face.  Walk off by scrambling to climber's right down that end of the formation.

climbs.name: Warthog variation
climbs.fa: Bob Gaines and Ron Herschberg, April 2003.

content.description: Climb about 30 feet up the initial ramp of Fote Hog, then move right, underclinging a slanting roof. Continue up a thin flake to join Fote Hog near the top of its first pitch.

climbs.name: Sentinel Beach
climbs.fa: Alan Bartlett and Katie Wilkinson, May 1988

content.description: Climb a seam to a right-facing book.  This is a dreadfully loose, grainy route, with fairly poor protection.
content.protection: standard rack (but you won't be able to place much gear)
content.location: This climb starts high on the left face, just left of a tree.

climbs.name: Look Ma, No Bolts
climbs.fa: Bob Gaines and Kurt Stitz, January 1992.

content.description:
This is a variation to Fote Hog. While it climbs a more direct line, it is considerably more runnout.

Start on Fote Hog. Climb the ramp up to the tree, then climb straight up as per Fote Hog. Where Fote Hog traverses right, move up and left, face climbing on positive edges (5.6 R) up to a small roof (good pro here). Pull over the roof (5.7-) then head slightly right up a steep, juggy face, pulling over a bulge (5.7), to a nice flat belay ledge with a small pine tree.

Pitch 2: (5.4) Face climb up and left to a crack that leads to the top.

climbs.name: Hog Trough
climbs.fa: Alan Bartlett and Mary-Ann Kelly, July 1998

content.description:
Climb right of the trough, below the cave-like feature.

From the cave, climb out the bulge on the left to gain easy holds and merge with Fote Hog.
content.protection: several seams and cracks take small cams and nuts

climbs.name: Hog Heaven
climbs.fa: Don Reid, Alan Bartlett, Derek Reinig, 1998 [per Miramontes 2d ed.]

content.description: Start as for Fote Hog, but continue left to thin cracks that go up; traverse back right at the horizontal then up crisscross cracks to a ledge.  [per Miramontes]
This is a fairly nice wide crack.
content.location: This obvious offwidth is well to the right of Western Saga.

content.description:
This route is to the climber's right of Ball Bearing.

P1: Follow a large ramp to an easy fifth class face. Climb straight up following a thin crack.  Traverse on small ledges under a roof below the patinas.  Climb through the patinas and build a belay at a flake with a vertical finger crack.

P2: Climb the flake, traverse to right and climb the obvious dihedral.  Move through a broken gap in the rock and build a belay at the top.  Exit climbers left.

Climbs through series of indistinct ledges and grainy slabs.  Crux occurs during a right-facing exfoliating big flake right before top-out.  Can also finish on patina knobs to right or bigger holds to left.
content.protection: First chance, wonky licheny .1 BD a ways up.  Got a #11 hex sitting on big crystals slightly left of route.  Equalized big, solid stoppers in flake.
content.location: Scramble to get to far left side of east face.  Starts on a boulder.  Anchor crack is set back from edge to left side.

content.description: Ball Bearing lies on the East Face of The Sentinel. Start left of Fote Hog (5.7) in left-trending finger crack that protects nicely with smaller size cams. Move right along horizontal crack and gain another left-trending crack. When this crack runs out just below the anchors, make a couple of spicy face moves to the 2-bolt anchor. Either rap from here (~100') or continue up second pitch. First pitch is generally well-protected. The second pitch is a bit spicy off the belay.
content.protection:
Nothing bigger than #2 Camalot. Double set of TCU's are helpful.

Bolted mid- point anchor (1/2" SS)
